content.description: Straight in, slightly left leaning, tight hands.
content.protection: #1s. We used a single #2 down low.
content.location: Turn left at the sport climbs when you first get to the wall. Follow the trail until you see the obvious splitter in the middle of a face with the juniper at the base.

content.description: Finger crack on a featured section of the wall for feet.
content.protection: Finger size pieces. Mostly .4 with a couple .5 and maybe a .75
content.location: Around the corner, left of the #1 hand crack with juniper tree start.

content.description: Start with tight hands to hands. Work your way up to a chimney/stembox to a ramp, then through another squeeze to the top.
content.location: Turn left at the two sport climbs when you first get to the wall. The route is on a N/NW aspect. Bolts with sling can be seen on the approach. This is the second route on the wall in Karl Kelly's book.

content.description:
Clip up about 7 or 8 draws to the chains. This line ascends the left side of the overhanging juggy face. 4 star climbing and movement on 2 star rock. This climb will be a 4 star line if it cleans up over time.

I don't know the name and the grade is based off my estimation. I am not the FA or bolter, don't know who put in the work but this thing is too good to not share. There is a bolted sport line to the right that looks much harder (11+/12-?)
content.protection: 7 or 8 bolts and a 2 bolt anchor with chains.
content.location: The left side of Habitado. When you take the main trail up you'll see a juggy overhanging face. Both sport routes tackle the cave. This line is the left.

content.description: Climb a small left-facing corner with perfect hands.  Pass a few rests with good feet before a short bulgy crux move.  The crack pinches down near the top, but a long reach out left gets you to a jug.
content.location:
Right side of the wall, about 20' left of

Lightning Bolt Crack

.  Look for the left-facing 1-2 foot corner.

content.description:
Fun offwidth corner that starts on big 4s (crux), then enters a lower angle flared chimney that alternates between sections of 5s, 6s, with some features to help you push up. The start may be fists for those with large enough paws, or knee locks for those with small enough knees, and for everyone else it's a sustained terrible size. Gotta love offwidthing.

If anyone knows who put up the FA, the official grade or name, please let me know. I'm guessing it's 10-.
content.protection: Protects well with ~3 #4s, a couple 5s and 6s which you can bump. You could place a 7 or two if you wanted. Two bolts on the top with no chains but had cord and carabiners to lower off.
content.location: The wide corner crack/chimney on the left side of habitado which has a chasm at the bottom, and chains inside the chimney where you can only just see them from the ground when looking with the right angle.

content.description:
Bit of a guess at the name; there is a broken plaque at the base of the route that reads "Prick (broken) Peak  5.(broken)". About 10 feet of tips up a steep slab and shallow right facing corner leads through the crux and up to a low-angle, right-facing flare with a good finger crack that slowly widens near the top.  Follow the crack to the anchors. Good, moderate climbing after the crux.  Crux protected well with blue alien and #1 BD C3, then up through the sizes to #2.

Not really sure on the rating,,, the crux felt really desperate to me.  The name, FA, and rating may need some future revisions.
content.location: Route located about 30 feet right of "Back in the Saddle" and 50 feet left of "Shayna's First Big Wall".  There is a deep flare immediately to the right with a faint plaque reading "Dead Reckoning".

content.description:
An offwidth corner with big rests.  You could lieback it, go straight in, or mix it up.  It starts fat and quickly gets to #5-#6 width.  There are several big rests on ledges inside and outside the crack.

You can easily set up a TR from

Lightning Bolt Crack

.
content.location:
Right side of the area, just 5-10' right of

Lightning Bolt Crack

.  Look for the offwidth corner to the right a beautiful but short lightning bolt crack.

content.description: Climb the obvious zig-zagging splitter to a big belay ledge. Great hands the whole way. Avoid the big, detached flake on the left side. Enjoy the finish that gets a bit wider!
content.protection: Mosty #2 Camalots. Maybe a couple 3's at the top. A #1 would fit at the beginning but probably not necessary.
content.location: Walk to the right along the cliff band, This climb is slightly recessed and hidden from view if you are in the wash. After the main 5.10 routes come around a boulder to find this obvious line!

content.description: Small hands to a good ledge then 15 feet of offwidth
content.location: Right of mariposa, shares anchors. labeled with sandstone slab.

content.description: Scramble up a boulder/ramp leaning against wall (4th class), watch out for a couple loose blocks. Place gear in a hand size crack and make a move left to an offset finger crack. Climb through fingers, off fingers, to good hands and wide hands to chains on the left. The offset and a horizontal make the low crux a bit little easier.

Climb the low angle ramp and step left to the crack. Climb overhung .4 through .75. Take a hang and wave at your buddies over on the left as they hang too and your belayer remarks that "Everybody's Hangin"
content.location: This is two to the right of Shayna's First Big Wall. Get the Creek Freak guide book to locate that route.

content.description:
Mostly thin hands to fingers crack in changing corner that passes a couple of pods.

The guide book describes this as a #1 camalot crack, but there is a variety of gear on it. I found the crux to be up high and protected by 0.75 camalots. The final move can be protected by a 0.5, but it isn't necessary.

While nothing bigger than a 1 is necessary, there are opportunities to place bigger gear to conserve 1s.

The bottom 20 feet has some features to the left that are unnecessary for the climb but tempting, but also very crumbly.
content.protection: Optional 0.5, 5x0.75, 8x#1, (optional, 2x#2, 2x#3, 1x#4, I only placed bigger stuff to save #1s, if you have more #1s, the bigger stuff isn't needed)
content.location: About 100 feet to the right of Mariposa corner, starting in a nice flat spot.

content.description:
Awkward hands very quickly gives way to good hands, offset tight hands, off fingers and fingers as this beautiful line arcs right. Not sure if the offset makes the crux harder or easier, or maybe both at different times. There are some face holds, and a wedge with an impressive pile of guano. You can crimp and side-pull around it to the good finger locks. Sweet!

The anchor situation involves three widely spaced bolts. Best to plan to rap off.
content.location: Just a bit right of Esta Dia Bonita

content.description:
SI Finger wedge to flare. (Sorry if my climbing jargon is off) Its a bit awkward, and the offset top might give you the fire shits. The name sake

To the right of (I think) Shannon's big wall
content.protection: 00 metolius- #1 totem(better for the flare at the top) I don't have 000 metolius but it might fit better then the 00.  On the FA a mega flared #5 BD was used to drill anchors.
content.location: To the right of (I think) Shannon's big wall

content.description: Fun overhanging sport climbing at Indian Creek??? Yep!  Climbing a thin finger crack using big huecos to the right for 20' (small gear), then transition to steep overhanging hueco jugs past three bolts.  Short, pumpy, and fun!
content.protection: Small cams, a handful of draws.
content.location: The left side of the obvious hueco-filled overhang near the prow of the cliff.
